M. EDITORS JOSEPHINE ELIZABETH RAYNE EFFIE LOUISE CHAPMAN, A. B. Stanbop€ Ptcee F. H. GILSON COMPANY BOSTON, U. S. A. '4 n * ^5 INTRODUCTION The New-England Historic Genealogical Society was granted a charter by the General Court of the Commonwealth of Massachu- setts, March 18, 1845, "for the purpose of collecting, preserving, and occasionally publishing, genealogical and historical matter, relating to early New England families, and for the establishment and main- tenance of a cabinet." Within a year from its incorporation the Society leased a room from the City of Boston in a building recently erected near the City Hall at the corner of City Hall Avenue ana Williams Court, and now occupied as a police station. This room was at the rear of the third floor, had three windows looking out into the Court, and was twenty-two feet long by seventeen feet wide. In this room on January 15, 1846, were deposited the books, pamphlets and manuscripts which formed the nucleus of the Society's Library and which up to that time had been in the possession of the several directors. A single book-case was sufficient to hold the entire library and, had the Society then possessed one copy of each Ameri- can publication devoted wholly to genealogy, a single shelf would have been ample for that division of its library. Up to this date there had been but little interest manifested in genealogy in America, and the occasional visitor in quest of data relating to American families found no indexes, demanded none, and needed none, for a few hours sufficed to examine page by page all the printed work on the subject. During the year 1845 various suggestions for publications were considered by the Society and by special committees appointed for the purpose, and on January 17, 1846, two days after the actual founding of the Library, action was taken by the Society which resulted in the establishment of The New-England Historical and Genealogical Register. The first number was issued on February 5, M \i l\ TRODl CTION 1847 ami, with but little change in its plan or scope, the Eti has continued to appear quarterly ever since. The iirst volume contained 400 pages — a very modest annual undertaking when the magnitude of the Society's work is considered, but less so when compared with the entire printed genealogical output of the pre- ceding two and a quarter centuries in New England. During this period the chief genealogical books were Farmer's J: r (352 pages), Mitchell's Bridgewater (400 pages), Deane's Scituate (412 pages), Thayer's Memorial (280 pages), Dodd's East-Haven Register (200 pages), Kilbourn Genealogy (151 pages), Sharpies Genealogy (136 pages), Shattuck's Concord (400 pages), Felt's Ipswich (320 pages), Coffin's Newbury (416 pages), and the Goddard genealogy (96 pages). The first volume of the Register was supplied with a partial index of persons, containing the names of " about all the individ- uals concerning whom particular mention " was made in the volume, but excepting those embraced in several long lists and ''Family Genealogies." It was then deemed needless and inexpedient to insert in the index the names from these lists though they amounted to thousands. This index, filling ten pages of three columns each, nonpareil type, probably contained less than half the names printed in the volume, and yet it was far superior to any index that had previously appeared in the same field. In the second volume there was both improvement and retrogression: improvement in the matter of the index being complete as far as surnames were con- cerned, but retrogression due to the omission of the Christian names. The index was thus reduced from one of persons to one of surnames. From the second to the forty-second volumes inclusive the indexes supplied were but bare lists of surnames averaging less than ten pages of four columns, nonpareil type. In the two decades following the establishment of the Library and the Register, interest in genealogy, awakened by these two potent forces, developed so rapidly, and genealogical publica- tions became so numerous, that there was a general demand for better indexes to facilitate research. Responding to this de- mand, the late William Henry Whit more prepared for publication INTRODUCTION vii a " General Index of Names for the First Twenty Volumes of the Register." This, it was estimated, would make a book of about 200 octavo pages. A prospectus for it was issued, calling for 250 subscribers at $3.00 each, signed by W. H. Whitmore, Edmund F. Slafter, William B. Towne, William B. Trask, John Ward Dean, Jeremiah Colburn and C. W. Tut tie. Arrangements were made with Messrs. Wiggin and Lunt of Boston to publish the work, but the subscriptions received did not warrant the publication. Before two more decades had passed it became evident that better indexes in the annual volumes of the Register were essential. The Publishing Committee for 1889, consisting of Messrs. Albert H. Hoyt, Francis H. Brown, Henry H. Edes, John T. Hassam and Frank E. Bradish, devised the system of indexing used in the forty-third and all succeeding volumes. The new indexes, which were intended to reduce the student's labor to a minimum, proved in every way satisfactory and still further emphasized the need of a similar consolidated index for all of the preceding volumes. On February 6, 1883 Mr. John T. Hassam, at a meeting of the Directors of the Society, "spoke of the importance of a full index to the whole series of volumes of the Register," and plans by which it could be accomplished were discussed. Thirteen years later, February 3, 1896, Mr. Hassam brought up the matter of an index at a meeting of the Society's Council and it was "Voted that a committee of three be appointed by the Chair to consider the sub- ject of a consolidated index to all the volumes of the New-England Historical and Genealogical Register." The chair appointed John T. Hassam, Julius H. Tuttle and John Ward Dean. Mr. Tuttle declined to serve and Mr. George Kuhn Clarke was appointed March 30, 1896 to fill the vacancv. On May 4, 1896 this Committee was authorized by the Council "to make such contracts and agreements in relation to said index, either for the whole or any part of the same, with such persons or corporations and on such terms, as may seem to them expedient: all payments to be made only from such moneys as shall have been subscribed and paid in to the Treasurer of this Society for said pur- pose — the said Society not to be pecuniarily liable in any sum viii INTRODUCTION exceeding the amount so paid to the Treasurer." The Committee estimated the cost of preparation of the proposed index, exclusive of printing, to be about $3000. They issued an appeal for funds and received from the following donors a total of $2420.92, in sums varying from $1 to $200: A. C. Adams, Boston. Francis Olcott Allen, Chestnut Hill, Pa. Mrs. Mary E. For about five years, work was in progress under contracts with the Committee. In November, 1901, having expended the amount donated for the purpose, the Committee asked the Council of the Society to advance money for the prosecution of the work. A total of $6500 was advanced while Mr. Hassam was chairman of the Committee and was expended under his direction until his death, April 22, 1903, in the compilation and verification of the Index. Mr. Dean died January 22, 1902, and Mr. William Prescott Greenlaw was appointed in his place on the Committee June 4, 1902. Mr. William Taggard Piper was appointed to take Mr. Has- sam's place on the Committee May 6, 1903. He resigned October 7, 1903, and Mr. James Swift Rogers was appointed chairman of the Committee. May 4, 1904 Mr. Nathaniel Cushing Nash was chosen to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Mr. George Kuhn Clarke, November 4, 1903. After the death of Mr. Rogers, Mr. Francis Apthorp Foster was appointed chairman, May 3, 1905. Following Mr. Hassam's death, the work of verification was continued and finished on the plan adopted by him. In the summer of 1904 the Committee, with Mr. Rogers as chairman, issued a prospectus wThich practically offered to publish the Index at cost if 200 subscribers were secured. This number being assured, the work of printing began in 1905 under contract with the F. H. Gilson Company of Boston. The Committee believe that they have secured the lowest cost for printing and editing consistent with good work, and they have endeavored to finish the task begun by their predecessors in a man- ner creditable to the Society and satisfactory to the subscribers. It is their intention to complete the publication without profit or INTRODUCTION xi loss to the Society and equitably to all subscribers. They are en- deavoring to dispose of the remaining unsold sets of the Index while the work is in progress. Owners of nearly complete sets of the Register will find it to their advantage to secure the Index before it is out of print. Five of the rarest volumes of the Reg- ister can scarcely be bought to-day for double the price of the Index, yet a nearly complete set of the Register with the Index, after this is out of print, will probably be worth more, both for use and intrinsically, than a complete set without the Index. The Committee desire unanimously to record their appreciation of the skill, ability and interest shown by Miss Rayne and Miss Chapman in editing the Index. They were transferred from the Library Staff of the Society to take charge of this work because of their thorough knowledge of cataloguing and indexing. The Committee feel that the results obtained have more than justified them in their selection. Register Vagaries. — In connection with the use of the Index of Persons in volume 1 to 50 of the Register, the discovery was made of a second edition of the January 1850 number of the Register (vol. 4), with results seriously affect- ing the indexing of pages 19 to 24, inclusive, The Index of Persons was I on the Jirst edition — hence apparent errors of reference so far as the second edition is concerned. The addition of new material to Nash's " Records of Say- brook, Ct.." beginning on page 19, and inserted without any reference to the fact, is responsible for the trouble. In the earlier volumes of the Register it was customary to stitch in or paste in any plate (or plates) , to accompany the number, opposite the first page of the text, irrespective of the position it (or they) should occupy when bound up. [Reprinted from Register for April, 1910, vol. 64, pp. 190-1.] LETTER OF HENRY WOLLCOTT.e To the Editor of the Register. Dear Sir: — You published in your Register of Oct., 1848, (p. 373, 374,) an interesting letter from John Wolcott, of England, to his brother, Henry Wolcott, of Connecticut, written in 1639, and communicated by my kinsman, George Gibbs, Esq., of New York City. I send, herewith, a brief letter, of less interest, but of a still earlier date, written the year af- ter Mr. Henry Wollcott emigrated to America, from John Wolcott, jr., to his cousin, Henry Wollcott, jr. The " Brother Simon," named in the letter, was the ancestor of the Connecticut Governors. He was the youngest of the family ; and, at the date of this letter, was only six years of age. It appears that he remained in England with his " sisters," Anna and Mary, until the parents and three elder sons had effected a settlement in this coun- try ; with the evident understanding that their brother, Henry, jr., was to return for them. " The rest of the Brothers " were George and Christo- pher. The " Brother John," who remained in England, leading, it would seem, an irregular life, is a. name new to our Genealogy. Our ancient " Family Chronologie " is silent respecting him. He had died, without is- sue surviving, previous to the date of his father's will, in 1655. Yours, respectfully, June 16, 1849. Saml. Wolcott. Letter of John Wollcott, Junior. Cozen Henry my love to you remembrd and to your father and mother to your Brothers these are to give you to understand that we are all in good health my father hath remembred his love to you ,and to your father and mother and to the rest oim your Brothers these are to give you to under- stand that your brother Simon hath been verre sicke of late and soehath your sisters alsoe But now thanks be to almightie god they are resonabelly wel againe Your Brother John continues in his ould Course of livinge. We shall al desire to have your Companie With us soe soone as Conven- iently you [can] good Cozen let me Intreate you to write to me of the man- ner and situation of the Country I have sent you in your Box a quire of paper be kause you shall remember to write unto me soe in hast I levinge you to the prtexion of the almightie god I end and restt. Your Inseperabel Cozen Wellington 22 July i63i John Wollcott (Superscribed) To his Lovinge Cozes Henry Wollcott Junior in Matapan (Dorchester) these in new England e This title (which should be letter to Henry Wollcott) and the two letters following it are printed line for line as they appeared in the first edition of the January L850 Rec I8TEE, page 23 (vide supra). Line three of the second letter commences page 24.
